Description: Narrow cylindrical hinge made of bone from a small chest or casket. In two pieces; pierced in centre; pointed ridge at centre of outder edge.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Previously dated 305BC–30BC, possibly based on an EEF 'Ptolemaic date. Parallels known from 2nd to 1st century BC Pompeii, after which the form changes (Cool 2016, 172-178). Possibly from a casket, known from Roman grave contexts (ibid.). Late 3rd century BC example was found in Philimina (Andrianou 2009, 73-74). Andrianou, D. 2009. The furniture and furnishings of ancient Greek houses and tombs. Cambridge University Press. Cool, H. E. M. 2016. The small finds and vessel glass from Insula VI.1 Pompeii: Excavations 1995-2006. Oxford: Archaeopress, Roman Archaeology 17.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (QJ.20)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
